stem: A 19-year-old client with a tibial fracture and a full leg cast reports 'unbearable' pain. Review the provided documentation. Which nursing intervention is most appropriate?

options.text: Notify the surgeon immediately and prepare for cast removal or bivalving.
Elevate the affected limb above the level of the heart.
Apply ice packs over the cast to reduce swelling.
Administer an additional dose of IV morphine as prescribed.

rationale.correct: The client's symptoms (unbearable pain unrelieved by morphine, pain with passive stretch, pallor, paresthesia, weak pulse, prolonged capillary refill) are indicative of compartment syndrome, a surgical emergency. The priority is to notify the surgeon immediately (a1) and prepare for interventions to relieve the pressure, such as cast removal or bivalving. Elevating the limb (a2) is contraindicated as it can further reduce arterial perfusion.
clinicalPearls: Compartment syndrome is characterized by the 6 Ps: Pain (out of proportion to injury, especially with passive stretch), Pressure, Paresthesia, Pallor, Paralysis, and Pulselessness (late sign).
Early recognition and intervention are crucial to prevent permanent muscle and nerve damage.
Never elevate a limb with suspected compartment syndrome.

questionTrap.trap: Choosing elevation (a2) or ice (a3) might seem appropriate for swelling, but they are contraindicated in compartment syndrome because they can worsen ischemia.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Recognize the signs of compartment syndrome (especially pain out of proportion and pain with passive stretch). Understand that elevation and ice are not appropriate when arterial perfusion is compromised.

mnemonic.title: Compartment Syndrome: 6 Ps
mnemonic.expansion: Pain (out of proportion), Pressure, Paresthesia, Pallor, Paralysis, Pulselessness.

exhibits.title: Neurovascular Assessment
exhibits.content:
Current Assessment:
Pain: 10/10, not relieved by 4mg IV morphine.
Pain increases significantly with passive dorsiflexion of the toes.
Skin: Pale and tense.
Capillary refill: > 5 seconds.
Dorsalis pedis pulse: +1 (Weak).

exhibits.title: Vital Signs
exhibits.content:
Vital Signs:
BP: 152/88 mmHg (Pain-related)
HR: 112 bpm
RR: 22 breaths/min

Client Presentation: Client is restless and guarding the affected limb.

exhibits.title: Medical History
exhibits.content:
Relevant History:
Tibial fracture occurred 12 hours ago.
Full leg cast applied 4 hours ago.

Sensory Changes: Client reports 'tingling' (paresthesia) in the web space between the first and second toes.
